intro: Perebea australis, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its strap-shaped leaves that can grow up to several meters in length. The plant is known for its fibrous bark, which has been traditionally used by Māori for making clothing and baskets. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in forest understories. The flowers are small and greenish, typically appearing in clusters at the base of the leaves.
